head.title: Summing Up: Is Our House Divided by Race?; Hawaii's Melting Pot

hedline.hl1: Summing Up: Is Our House Divided by Race?; Hawaii's Melting Pot

abstract.p: Patrick Hunter letter on series on racial relations comments on ethnic diversity in Hawaii

block.p: Re your series ''How Race Is Lived in America'':

Re your series ''How Race Is Lived in America'':

I am a white man who lived in Hawaii for three years. For the first time in my life, after having been raised in an upper-middle-class white neighborhood on the mainland, I was no longer a member of the majority but just one of many in an ethnic hodgepodge of people.
Did I have advantages there as a white person that someone else may not have had? Probably. Hawaii is not perfect. The disadvantage of the native Hawaiians is an example of Hawaii's imperfections.

On the mainland, asking someone about his ethnicity is taken as an insult. In Hawaii, that question is asked as an introduction, out of interest in a person's family and culture. Now that I live on the mainland, I admit that I am much more conscious of race. I seek out ''my kind.'' In Hawaii, I sought out diversity. America, and its polarity, does that to us all.
